content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" is cited as the short title. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties, prohibiting non-compliance with royalty payment requirements. The Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Violations include failure to pay royalties, submitting false information, and misleading reports, with penalties of three times the unpaid royalty amount plus interest. The Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 now includes civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Violations may result in penalties of $25,000 per violation per day, or three times the unpaid royalty amount plus interest. Violations can be avoided if reported and corrected within 30 days. Additionally, failure to notify the Secretary of any designation under section 102(a) may result in lease administration violations. Failure to comply with lease administration requirements, such as designations under section 102(a) or obligations under a lease, may result in penalties. This includes failure to permit lawful entry, inspection, or audit, as well as non-compliance with notification requirements for production. Failure to comply with lease administration requirements, such as designations under section 102(a) or obligations under a lease, may result in penalties of up to $10,000 per violation for each day the violation continues. Theft of oil or gas without legal authority or involvement in unauthorized transactions can also lead to penalties. Failure to comply with lease administration requirements may result in penalties of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Purchasing, accepting, selling, transporting, or conveying stolen or unlawfully removed oil or gas can lead to penalties of up to $25,000 per violation per day without correction. Repeated violations will result in notification and demand for compliance. Failure to comply with lease administration requirements may result in penalties of up to $10,000 per violation per day. A person notified must correct violations within 30 days. Failure to comply with the demand may result in a civil penalty equal to 3 times the original penalty. Repeated violations may lead to additional penalties or compliance demands by the Secretary. The Secretary may take various actions if a person fails to comply with lease administration requirements, including shutting in production, prohibiting lease acquisition, canceling or transferring lease interests, and collecting reimbursement for costs incurred. The Secretary has the authority to take actions such as shutting in production, prohibiting lease acquisition, and collecting reimbursement for costs incurred if a person fails to comply with lease administration requirements. Any determination of royalties or penalties owed shall be final unless an administrative appeal is filed within 15 days. The Secretary has the authority to make final determinations on penalties in accordance with regulations. The amount of penalties can be deducted from sums owed by the United States. The Secretary can compromise or reduce penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties shall be served personally or by registered mail. The Secretary designates a representative to receive notices under this subsection. The Secretary determines penalty amounts and reasons for his decisions. Judicial review of final orders can be sought in the United States district court. The Secretary designates a representative to receive notices and determines penalty amounts. Judicial review of final orders can be sought in the United States district court within 90 days after the Secretary's final order. Failure to pay a civil penalty may result in legal action. The court can award the assessed amount plus interest after a final judgment in favor of the Secretary. No civil penalty for failure to pay rental on a lease terminated under the Mineral Leasing Act. Any violation determination tolls statutes of limitation. The violation determination tolls statutes of limitation for oil and gas leases until corrected or a final order is issued. The person must maintain all records related to their leases. The person must maintain all records related to their oil and gas leases until released by the Secretary or until the records must be maintained under section 103(b). Amounts received by the United States in actions for underpayment of royalties will be treated as royalties paid under the lease for mineral leasing laws. The United States is under a lease for mineral leasing laws and the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965. SEC. 3. SHARED CIVIL PENALTIES. Amendment to the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 to increase civil penalties for violations.
